heading: rants & raves

author: wired blogs
text: date: wed., 11/1/00 7:41 am from: joe (joe@root.com)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: did smut spammers scam google?regarding your story about google ("did smut spammers scam google?," nov. 1, 2000), i'd like to say that google may have a "spam-proof" algorithm, but that does not make it especially good at listing the obvious.type in "texas rebel radio" and you won't even get the site http://www.texasrebelradio.com, but two pages of others that are useless. but type "texas fan radio" and it's the first one listed.there lots of other similar examples that can and have made even google worthless for many searches. having a large number of links to a page does not necessarily make a page useful or even popular, and like all search engines, as it has grown in size, its usefulness has declined and not improved. as the road forks, so too must the computational power to descend down those forks, to find the nearest rest stop on the digital dirt road.
